Award.AwardTitle: Mechanisms of Fluid Feeding in Insects, from Nanoscale to Organism
Award.AbstractNarration:
Fluid-feeding insects are among the most abundant organisms on Earth. Their success can be attributed in part to their tubular mouthparts, engineered by natural selection to acquire a remarkable variety of fluids, such as blood and nectar. These feeding devices - proboscises - must take up fluids while remaining free of sticky residues and debris that might impede fluid uptake; in other words, they must be capable of self-cleaning. The fundamental organization of the proboscis consists of a slender tube with a surface of minute valleys and ridges that form canals connected by pores to a central food canal. The research focuses on the hypothesis that fluid feeding can be explained by a single model based on unifying principles of capillarity and wetting. To examine this primary hypothesis, two major insect groups, butterflies and flies, will be used to study the structure and function of the proboscis. The study is organized around three objectives: (1) to explain the role of wettability of the proboscis as the first step in acquiring fluid, (2) to elucidate the mechanisms of fluid uptake as the second step in fluid acquisition, and (3) to explain how the availability of fluid, whether in pools or films, determines the means of uptake. The project offers a new framework for explaining biological phenomena, such as dietary choices and the diversification of insect life. It also provides a platform for transferring Nature-inspired principles of fluid uptake and transport to the development of new engineering devices, such as flexible microfluidic probes. The research program emphasizes cross-disciplinary interaction between biologists and physical scientists and translation into interdisciplinary education of students, from high school onward. Outreach to students, including those in under-represented groups, by providing research opportunities and by hosting science teachers to develop teaching modules emphasizing the relation of physical principles to aspects of Nature, such as butterfly feeding and pollination. Research results will be incorporated into courses at two universities and will be disseminated through paper and electronic publications, professional and public presentations, and student-developed web sites and blogs.

The proposed study launches from preliminary work by the investigators, which indicates that fluid feeding by insects can be captured under a single model based on unifying principles of capillarity and wetting (hydrophilicity and hydrophobicity), which heretofore have been poorly explored. Tools and principles will be used to provide a quantitative, comparative analysis of the (1) micro-architecture of the mouthparts (e.g., scanning electron microscopy, X-ray tomography), (2) role and function of micro-architecture in acquiring and transporting fluids into and through the mouthparts (e.g., X-ray phase-contrast imaging, fluorescent and dark-field optical microscopy, and mathematical image analysis), (3) materials wetting and fluid flow through different conduits (physical and mathematical modeling augmented by full characterization of fluid properties such as food rheology, surface tension, and contact angles), and (4) hydrophilic-hydrophobic properties of the mouthparts (e.g., confocal microscopy, fluorescent imaging, Atomic force microscopy).

POR.DRECONTENT:
More than half of all insects, including bees, butterflies, moths, and flies, are fluid feeders with specially constructed mouthparts for acquiring small amounts of fluid. The project leaders sought to understand the structure and function of the insect feeding device, called a “proboscis”—a remarkable example of natural engineering. The investigators discovered that the proboscis of butterflies and moths is similar to a sponge plus a straw and functions to acquire fluid in four fundamental stages. First, a film of liquid, such as floral nectar, covers the proboscis. This stage is followed by directed movement of the liquid to a porous seam along the midline. Next, absorption occurs as the fluid moves through tiny openings along the seam and into the food canal. In the final step, a suction pump operated by muscles in the insect’s head delivers the fluid to the digestive system.

            The research team discovered that when a butterfly bends its proboscis, such as while feeding from a flower or coiling it after feeding, it causes fluid to move to the porous seam, aided by the surface texture of the proboscis. The porous seam is where the two halves of the proboscis come together when the butterfly assembles its feeding device after emerging from the pupa. Theoretical and experimental analyses showed that capillary forces from butterfly saliva bring together and hold the two halves of the proboscis while small hooks unite them, forming a central food canal. Thus, saliva plays a key role in an integrated mechanical and behavioral process of proboscis self-assembly, and it is important in self-repair of the proboscis if the two halves come apart. A well-hydrated insect that is able to produce enough saliva to hold the two halves together is essential for optimal feeding efficiency. The investigators also discovered that butterflies and flies both have a limiting pore size in the food sources (e.g., rotting fruit) from which they can withdraw fluids. Furthermore, the results indicated that food sources of butterflies have driven the structural diversity of proboscises and that a particular proboscis architecture enhances feeding abilities of each species on a particular type of food, such as nectar versus sap. By analyzing flow inside the proboscis and the suction pump, the researchers discovered that fluid-feeding insects can be classified into two groups, depending on the mechanism of energy dissipation. Insects with long proboscises spend energy primarily on moving fluid through the proboscis to the suction pump, whereas insects with short proboscises potentially expend muscular energy primarily on moving fluid through the pump. These different strategies of dissipating energy help explain the great diversity of fluid-feeding habits of insects.

             The investigators identified applications of their discoveries to artificial engineering, for example, in the medical and textile industries. Study of natural proboscises indicated the possibility of artificial microfluidic devices that are multifunctional, responsive to environmental stimuli, porous, strong, flexible, and capable of self-assembly and self-repair. Although the structural aspects of a natural proboscis can be engineered artificially, the researchers found that greater functionality is possible with natural proboscises because insects can behaviorally overcome physical constraints. For example, by making tiny adjustments in spacing between the two halves of the proboscis, the insect can reduce friction as fluid moves through the narrow food canal. Analysis of fluid movement on the proboscis surface provides a model for engineering applications involving fibers formed into loops. Metal meshes can be engineered similar to coiled butterfly proboscises so that thicker anti-corrosion coatings are deposited at ring contacts where water is likely to be trapped. In textile engineering, knitted fabrics can be designed with fiber loops similar to coiled butterfly proboscises so that the movement of liquid dyes produces color gradients, with the darkest colors in the layers of the loop nearest the loop axis and the palest colors in the outermost layers.

            The results of the research were disseminated through 11 publications in high-impact science journals, more than 80 research presentations at professional meetings and universities throughout the world, and web-posted videos of the methodology for various aspects of the work. The project served as a platform for science education and training of students. Nearly 50 individuals participated in the research, including 43 students from diverse backgrounds, who received integrated educational training in biology and engineering and subsequently launched higher degree programs and professional careers in science. The project personnel developed new university courses based on the research, such as an Honors course entitled “Bioinspired”, which features examples of natural engineering in the insect world as models for artificial engineering.
